Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After much debate, the fantasy realm 
you call home has decided dragon jousting may not be 
the best way to choose its leaders, and has begun transitioning to democracy. The candidates are a giant orange troll
and an experienced tree statesman. An all-powerful eyebrow has hired 
your company— The Dormor Polling Agency— to survey the citizens of the land
and predict who will win. There’s a lot riding on this: if you get it wrong, heads— 
well, your head— will quite literally roll. Your job is to go from door to door, asking voters whether they prefer
the troll or the treefellow and to use the results to project 
how the election will go. Your fellow citizens want you to succeed
and would tell you the truth... but there’s a problem. Few are willing to admit 
they support the troll on account of his controversial 
life choices. If you were to ask a troll supporter
who she'll vote for, there’s a good chance that she’ll claim 
to support the treeman, skewing your results. You’re about to begin your rounds when 
a stranger offers you some cryptic advice: “Here’s the question that will save your
neck: what have you got in your pocket?” You reach into your pocket and pull out...
a silver coin, which has the current king’s head 
on one side and his tail on the other. How can you use it to conduct
an accurate poll? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to use the coin 
to add random chance to your interaction that will give 
troll supporters deniability. In other words, you’re looking for 
a system where when someone says “troll,” it could either be because the coin 
somehow told them to, or because they actually 
support the troll— and you’d have no way to tell 
the difference. You’ll also need to know how frequently 
the coin skewed the results, so you can account
for it in your calculations. One solution is to have every pollee 
go into their house and flip the coin. If it lands heads, they should
tell you “troll,” whether or not they actually support him. If it lands tails, they should tell 
you their actual preference. Here’s what happens: you poll 200 voters, and 130 say 
they’ll vote for the troll. For about 50%, or 100 of them,
the coin will have landed heads. So you can subtract 100 troll votes 
off his total, and know the troll’s real support 
is 30 to 70, and he’s very likely to lose. The election comes around,
but before the results can be certified a third party candidate swoops in 
and burns the treefellow to a crisp. The freshly signed and deeply flawed
constitution mandates that this challenger gets to take his victim’s place 
in a new election. The Dormor Polling Agency sends you back 
out on the streets with your trusty coin. Only this time no one is comfortable
admitting their preference: supporting the troll is still shameful, and nobody wants to express support of a
dragon who murdered his way into the race. But your job is your job. 
How do you conduct an accurate poll now? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 This time, instead of masking 
just one candidate preference, you need some way to disguise both. At the same time, you also need to leave 
space for some portion of the people polled to express their true preference. But a coin toss only has two
possible outcomes... right? Suppose you have everyone
flip the coin twice— now there are four possible results. You can tell the people who flip heads
twice in a row to report support for the troll; those who get tails 
twice in a row to report dragon; and those with any other combination
to declare their true preference. The chances of getting either
two heads or two tails in a row are 50% times 50%— 
or 25%. Subtracting that proportion 
of the total respondents from each candidate’s score should 
give you something close to the real distribution. This time, 105 respondents announced 
themselves in favor of the troll and 95 for the dragon. Out of the total, the coin will make 25% or 50 respond troll 
and another 50 respond dragon. Subtracting 50 from each result reveals
that voters seem to prefer the troll by a margin of about 55 to 45. It’s close, but as predicted,
the troll wins the election, and you live to poll another day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose there are two candidates A and B. You poll 300 people with the following rule: each person P flips a fair coin twice. If the coin comes up heads both times, then P should vote for A. If the coin comes up tails both times, then P should vote for B. Otherwise P should vote for the candidate P prefers. If 20% of the people like A and 80% like B, approximately what poll score will A receive?
Options: A. 85, B. 95, C. 105, D. 110
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What method was previously used to choose leaders in the fantasy realm, but is now being replaced by democracy? Options: A. Dragon jousting, B. Coin flipping, C. Polling, D. Lottery Correct Option: A
Question 2: Why are some citizens reluctant to admit their support for the troll in the election? Options: A. Due to his lack of experience, B. Because of his controversial life choices, C. Since he is not a strong leader, D. As he is not charismatic Correct Option: B
Question 3: What object does the protagonist find in their pocket, which helps them conduct an accurate poll? Options: A. A silver ring, B. A silver coin, C. A magical amulet, D. A crystal ball Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does the protagonist use the coin to add random chance to the interaction and give troll supporters deniability? Options: A. By having every pollee flip the coin and tell the truth if it lands heads, B. By having every pollee flip the coin and tell the truth if it lands tails, C. By having every pollee go into their house and flip the coin, telling the protagonist "troll" if it lands heads and their actual preference if it lands tails, D. By having every pollee flip the coin and report the opposite of their actual preference Correct Option: C
Question 5: In the first poll, what percentage of voters are expected to have been influenced by the coin to say "troll"? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 100% Correct Option: B
Question 6: What event disrupts the election, causing a third-party candidate to enter the race? Options: A. A natural disaster, B. The treefellow's withdrawal, C. The troll's disqualification, D. The dragon burning the treefellow to a crisp Correct Option: D
Question 7: How does the protagonist adapt their polling method to account for the new challenge of both candidates being unpopular? Options: A. By using a different type of coin, B. By having pollees flip the coin twice to create four possible outcomes, C. By asking pollees to report their true preference directly, D. By using a different method altogether Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the expected proportion of respondents that will be influenced by the coin to report a specific candidate in the second poll? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 100% Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the predicted outcome of the election based on the second poll's results? Options: A. The dragon wins by a margin of 55 to 45, B. The troll wins by a margin of 55 to 45, C. The election is too close to call, D. The results are inconclusive Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the ultimate consequence for the protagonist if they fail to accurately predict the election outcome? Options: A. They will lose their job, B. They will be fined, C. Their head will literally roll, D. They will be imprisoned Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, I identified that Question 8 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ.

Question 8 asks about the expected proportion of respondents that will be influenced by the coin to report a specific candidate in the second poll, which is related to the concept of using a coin to add random chance to the interaction and accounting for its influence on the poll results. Although it does not directly ask about the poll score a candidate will receive, it deals with the same underlying idea of using a coin to mask preferences and calculating the expected outcome.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After much debate, the fantasy realm 
you call home has decided dragon jousting may not be 
the best way to choose its leaders, and has begun transitioning to democracy. The candidates are a giant orange troll
and an experienced tree statesman. An all-powerful eyebrow has hired 
your company— The Dormor Polling Agency— to survey the citizens of the land
and predict who will win. There’s a lot riding on this: if you get it wrong, heads— 
well, your head— will quite literally roll. Your job is to go from door to door, asking voters whether they prefer
the troll or the treefellow and to use the results to project 
how the election will go. Your fellow citizens want you to succeed
and would tell you the truth... but there’s a problem. Few are willing to admit 
they support the troll on account of his controversial 
life choices. If you were to ask a troll supporter
who she'll vote for, there’s a good chance that she’ll claim 
to support the treeman, skewing your results. You’re about to begin your rounds when 
a stranger offers you some cryptic advice: “Here’s the question that will save your
neck: what have you got in your pocket?” You reach into your pocket and pull out...
a silver coin, which has the current king’s head 
on one side and his tail on the other. How can you use it to conduct
an accurate poll? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to use the coin 
to add random chance to your interaction that will give 
troll supporters deniability. In other words, you’re looking for 
a system where when someone says “troll,” it could either be because the coin 
somehow told them to, or because they actually 
support the troll— and you’d have no way to tell 
the difference. You’ll also need to know how frequently 
the coin skewed the results, so you can account
for it in your calculations. One solution is to have every pollee 
go into their house and flip the coin. If it lands heads, they should
tell you “troll,” whether or not they actually support him. If it lands tails, they should tell 
you their actual preference. Here’s what happens: you poll 200 voters, and 130 say 
they’ll vote for the troll. For about 50%, or 100 of them,
the coin will have landed heads. So you can subtract 100 troll votes 
off his total, and know the troll’s real support 
is 30 to 70, and he’s very likely to lose. The election comes around,
but before the results can be certified a third party candidate swoops in 
and burns the treefellow to a crisp. The freshly signed and deeply flawed
constitution mandates that this challenger gets to take his victim’s place 
in a new election. The Dormor Polling Agency sends you back 
out on the streets with your trusty coin. Only this time no one is comfortable
admitting their preference: supporting the troll is still shameful, and nobody wants to express support of a
dragon who murdered his way into the race. But your job is your job. 
How do you conduct an accurate poll now? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 This time, instead of masking 
just one candidate preference, you need some way to disguise both. At the same time, you also need to leave 
space for some portion of the people polled to express their true preference. But a coin toss only has two
possible outcomes... right? Suppose you have everyone
flip the coin twice— now there are four possible results. You can tell the people who flip heads
twice in a row to report support for the troll; those who get tails 
twice in a row to report dragon; and those with any other combination

or 25%. Subtracting that proportion 
of the total respondents from each candidate’s score should 
give you something close to the real distribution. This time, 105 respondents announced 
themselves in favor of the troll and 95 for the dragon. Out of the total, the coin will make 25% or 50 respond troll 
and another 50 respond dragon. Subtracting 50 from each result reveals
that voters seem to prefer the troll by a margin of about 55 to 45. It’s close, but as predicted,
the troll wins the election, and you live to poll another day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose there are two candidates A and B. You poll 300 people with the following rule: each person P flips a fair coin twice. If the coin comes up heads both times, then P should vote for A. If the coin comes up tails both times, then P should vote for B. Otherwise P should vote for the candidate P prefers. If 20% of the people like A and 80% like B, approximately what poll score will B receive?
Options: A. 155, B. 185, C. 190, D. 195
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After much debate, the fantasy realm 
you call home has decided dragon jousting may not be 
the best way to choose its leaders, and has begun transitioning to democracy. The candidates are a giant orange troll
and an experienced tree statesman. An all-powerful eyebrow has hired 
your company— The Dormor Polling Agency— to survey the citizens of the land
and predict who will win. There’s a lot riding on this: if you get it wrong, heads— 
well, your head— will quite literally roll. Your job is to go from door to door, asking voters whether they prefer
the troll or the treefellow and to use the results to project 
how the election will go. Your fellow citizens want you to succeed
and would tell you the truth... but there’s a problem. Few are willing to admit 
they support the troll on account of his controversial 
life choices. If you were to ask a troll supporter
who she'll vote for, there’s a good chance that she’ll claim 
to support the treeman, skewing your results. You’re about to begin your rounds when 
a stranger offers you some cryptic advice: “Here’s the question that will save your
neck: what have you got in your pocket?” You reach into your pocket and pull out...
a silver coin, which has the current king’s head 
on one side and his tail on the other. How can you use it to conduct
an accurate poll? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to use the coin 
to add random chance to your interaction that will give 
troll supporters deniability. In other words, you’re looking for 
a system where when someone says “troll,” it could either be because the coin 
somehow told them to, or because they actually 
support the troll— and you’d have no way to tell 
the difference. You’ll also need to know how frequently 
the coin skewed the results, so you can account
for it in your calculations. One solution is to have every pollee 
go into their house and flip the coin. If it lands heads, they should
tell you “troll,” whether or not they actually support him. If it lands tails, they should tell 
you their actual preference. Here’s what happens: you poll 200 voters, and 130 say 
they’ll vote for the troll. For about 50%, or 100 of them,
the coin will have landed heads. So you can subtract 100 troll votes 
off his total, and know the troll’s real support 
is 30 to 70, and he’s very likely to lose. The election comes around,
but before the results can be certified a third party candidate swoops in 
and burns the treefellow to a crisp. The freshly signed and deeply flawed
constitution mandates that this challenger gets to take his victim’s place 
in a new election. The Dormor Polling Agency sends you back 
out on the streets with your trusty coin. Only this time no one is comfortable
admitting their preference: supporting the troll is still shameful, and nobody wants to express support of a
dragon who murdered his way into the race. But your job is your job. 
How do you conduct an accurate poll now? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 This time, instead of masking 
just one candidate preference, you need some way to disguise both. At the same time, you also need to leave 
space for some portion of the people polled to express their true preference. But a coin toss only has two
possible outcomes... right? Suppose you have everyone
flip the coin twice— now there are four possible results. You can tell the people who flip heads
twice in a row to report support for the troll; those who get tails 
twice in a row to report dragon; and those with any other combination
to declare their true preference. The chances of getting either
two heads or two tails in a row are 50% times 50%— 
or 25%. Subtracting that proportion 
of the total respondents from each candidate’s score should 
give you something close to the real distribution. This time, 105 respondents announced 
themselves in favor of the troll and 95 for the dragon. Out of the total, the coin will make 25% or 50 respond troll 
and another 50 respond dragon. Subtracting 50 from each result reveals
that voters seem to prefer the troll by a margin of about 55 to 45. It’s close, but as predicted,
the troll wins the election, and you live to poll another day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose there are three candidates A, B, C. You poll 800 people with the following rule: each person P flips a fair coin three times. If the coin comes up heads all three times, then P should vote for A. If the coin comes up tails all three times, then P should vote for B. Otherwise P should vote for the candidate P prefers. If 25% of the people like A and 40% like B and 35% like C, approximately what poll score will A receive?
Options: A. 190, B. 250, C. 370, D. 600
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What method was previously used to choose leaders in the fantasy realm, but is now being replaced by democracy? Options: A. Dragon jousting, B. Coin flipping, C. Polling, D. Lottery Correct Option: A
Question 2: Why are some citizens reluctant to admit their support for the troll in the election? Options: A. Due to his lack of experience, B. Because of his controversial life choices, C. Since he is not a strong leader, D. As he is not charismatic Correct Option: B
Question 3: What object does the protagonist find in their pocket, which helps them conduct an accurate poll? Options: A. A silver ring, B. A silver coin, C. A magical amulet, D. A crystal ball Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does the protagonist use the coin to add random chance to the interaction and give troll supporters deniability? Options: A. By having every pollee flip the coin and tell the truth if it lands heads, B. By having every pollee flip the coin and tell the truth if it lands tails, C. By having every pollee go into their house and flip the coin, telling the protagonist "troll" if it lands heads and their actual preference if it lands tails, D. By having every pollee flip the coin and report the opposite of their actual preference Correct Option: C
Question 5: In the first poll, what percentage of voters are expected to have been influenced by the coin to say "troll"? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 100% Correct Option: B
Question 6: What event disrupts the election, causing a third-party candidate to enter the race? Options: A. A natural disaster, B. The treefellow's withdrawal, C. The troll's disqualification, D. The dragon burning the treefellow to a crisp Correct Option: D
Question 7: How does the protagonist adapt their polling method to account for the new challenge of both candidates being unpopular? Options: A. By using a different type of coin, B. By having pollees flip the coin twice to create four possible outcomes, C. By asking pollees to report their true preference directly, D. By using a different method altogether Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the expected proportion of respondents that will be influenced by the coin to report a specific candidate in the second poll? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 100% Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the predicted outcome of the election based on the second poll's results? Options: A. The dragon wins by a margin of 55 to 45, B. The troll wins by a margin of 55 to 45, C. The election is too close to call, D. The results are inconclusive Correct Option: B

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, I identified that Question 8 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ.

Although the specific details of the questions differ, the underlying concept and the need to understand the influence of the coin on the poll results make Question 8 the most similar to the ground truth MCQ.

Question 10: What is the ultimate consequence for the protagonist if they fail to accurately predict the election outcome? Options: A. They will lose their job, B. They will be fined, C. Their head will literally roll, D. They will be imprisoned Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, I identified that Question 8 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ.

Question 8 asks about the expected proportion of respondents that will be influenced by the coin to report a specific candidate in the second poll, which is related to the concept of using a coin to add random chance to the interaction and accounting for its influence on the poll results. The ground truth MCQ also deals with a similar scenario, where respondents flip a coin three times to determine their vote, and the question asks about the expected poll score for a particular candidate.

Although the specific details of the questions differ, the underlying concept and the need to understand the influence of the coin on the poll results make Question 8 the most similar to the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
After much debate, the fantasy realm 
you call home has decided dragon jousting may not be 
the best way to choose its leaders, and has begun transitioning to democracy. The candidates are a giant orange troll
and an experienced tree statesman. An all-powerful eyebrow has hired 
your company— The Dormor Polling Agency— to survey the citizens of the land
and predict who will win. There’s a lot riding on this: if you get it wrong, heads— 
well, your head— will quite literally roll. Your job is to go from door to door, asking voters whether they prefer
the troll or the treefellow and to use the results to project 
how the election will go. Your fellow citizens want you to succeed
and would tell you the truth... but there’s a problem. Few are willing to admit 
they support the troll on account of his controversial 
life choices. If you were to ask a troll supporter
who she'll vote for, there’s a good chance that she’ll claim 
to support the treeman, skewing your results. You’re about to begin your rounds when 
a stranger offers you some cryptic advice: “Here’s the question that will save your
neck: what have you got in your pocket?” You reach into your pocket and pull out...
a silver coin, which has the current king’s head 
on one side and his tail on the other. How can you use it to conduct
an accurate poll? Pause here to figure it out yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to use the coin 
to add random chance to your interaction that will give 
troll supporters deniability. In other words, you’re looking for 
a system where when someone says “troll,” it could either be because the coin 
somehow told them to, or because they actually 
support the troll— and you’d have no way to tell 
the difference. You’ll also need to know how frequently 
the coin skewed the results, so you can account
for it in your calculations. One solution is to have every pollee 
go into their house and flip the coin. If it lands heads, they should
tell you “troll,” whether or not they actually support him. If it lands tails, they should tell 
you their actual preference. Here’s what happens: you poll 200 voters, and 130 say 
they’ll vote for the troll. For about 50%, or 100 of them,
the coin will have landed heads. So you can subtract 100 troll votes 
off his total, and know the troll’s real support 
is 30 to 70, and he’s very likely to lose. The election comes around,
but before the results can be certified a third party candidate swoops in 
and burns the treefellow to a crisp. The freshly signed and deeply flawed
constitution mandates that this challenger gets to take his victim’s place 
in a new election. The Dormor Polling Agency sends you back 
out on the streets with your trusty coin. Only this time no one is comfortable
admitting their preference: supporting the troll is still shameful, and nobody wants to express support of a
dragon who murdered his way into the race. But your job is your job. 
How do you conduct an accurate poll now? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 This time, instead of masking 
just one candidate preference, you need some way to disguise both. At the same time, you also need to leave 
space for some portion of the people polled to express their true preference. But a coin toss only has two
possible outcomes... right? Suppose you have everyone
flip the coin twice— now there are four possible results. You can tell the people who flip heads
twice in a row to report support for the troll; those who get tails 
twice in a row to report dragon; and those with any other combination
to declare their true preference. The chances of getting either
two heads or two tails in a row are 50% times 50%— 
or 25%. Subtracting that proportion 
of the total respondents from each candidate’s score should 
give you something close to the real distribution. This time, 105 respondents announced 
themselves in favor of the troll and 95 for the dragon. Out of the total, the coin will make 25% or 50 respond troll 
and another 50 respond dragon. Subtracting 50 from each result reveals
that voters seem to prefer the troll by a margin of about 55 to 45. It’s close, but as predicted,
the troll wins the election, and you live to poll another day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose there are three candidates A, B, C. You poll 800 people with the following rule: each person P flips a fair coin three times. If the coin comes up heads all three times, then P should vote for A. If the coin comes up tails all three times, then P should vote for B. Otherwise P should vote for the candidate P prefers. If 25% of the people like A and 40% like B and 35% like C, approximately what poll score will C receive?
Options: A. 210, B. 310, C. 200, D. 175
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What method was previously used to choose leaders in the fantasy realm, but is now being replaced by democracy? Options: A. Dragon jousting, B. Coin flipping, C. Polling, D. Lottery Correct Option: A
Question 2: Why are some citizens reluctant to admit their support for the troll in the election? Options: A. Due to his lack of experience, B. Because of his controversial life choices, C. Since he is not a strong leader, D. As he is not charismatic Correct Option: B
Question 3: What object does the protagonist find in their pocket, which helps them conduct an accurate poll? Options: A. A silver ring, B. A silver coin, C. A magical amulet, D. A crystal ball Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does the protagonist use the coin to add random chance to the interaction and give troll supporters deniability? Options: A. By having every pollee flip the coin and tell the truth if it lands heads, B. By having every pollee flip the coin and tell the truth if it lands tails, C. By having every pollee go into their house and flip the coin, telling the protagonist "troll" if it lands heads and their actual preference if it lands tails, D. By having every pollee flip the coin and report the opposite of their actual preference Correct Option: C
Question 5: In the first poll, what percentage of voters are expected to have been influenced by the coin to say "troll"? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 100% Correct Option: B
Question 6: What event disrupts the election, causing a third-party candidate to enter the race? Options: A. A natural disaster, B. The treefellow's withdrawal, C. The troll's disqualification, D. The dragon burning the treefellow to a crisp Correct Option: D
Question 7: How does the protagonist adapt their polling method to account for the new challenge of both candidates being unpopular? Options: A. By using a different type of coin, B. By having pollees flip the coin twice to create four possible outcomes, C. By asking pollees to report their true preference directly, D. By using a different method altogether Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the expected proportion of respondents that will be influenced by the coin to report a specific candidate in the second poll? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 100% Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the predicted outcome of the election based on the second poll's results? Options: A. The dragon wins by a margin of 55 to 45, B. The troll wins by a margin of 55 to 45, C. The election is too close to call, D. The results are inconclusive Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the ultimate consequence for the protagonist if they fail to accurately predict the election outcome? Options: A. They will lose their job, B. They will be fined, C. Their head will literally roll, D. They will be imprisoned Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ based on question intent, options, and content.

The ground truth MCQ is about predicting the poll score of a candidate (C) in a scenario where voters flip a coin three times to decide whether to report their true preference or vote for a specific candidate (A or B). The generated MCQs do not have an exact match for this scenario.

However, Question 8 is the most similar generated MCQ, as it discusses the expected proportion of respondents that will be influenced by the coin to report a specific candidate in the second poll. Although it does not involve calculating the poll score of a candidate, it deals with the concept of using a coin flip to influence respondents' answers.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Historically, most cars have run 
on gasoline, but that doesn’t have to be
the case in the future: other liquid fuels and electricity
can also power cars. So what are the differences 
between these options? And which one’s best? Gasoline is refined from crude oil, a fossil fuel extracted
from deep underground. The energy in gasoline comes from a class
of molecules called hydrocarbons. There are hundreds of different
hydrocarbons in crude oil, and different ones are used 
to make gasoline and diesel— which is why you can't use
them interchangeably. Fuels derived from crude oil
are extremely energy dense, bringing a lot of bang for your buck. Unfortunately, they have many drawbacks. Oil spills cause environmental damage
and cost billions of dollars to clean up. Air pollution from burning 
fossil fuels like these kills 4.5 million people each year. And transportation accounts for 16%
of global greenhouse gas emissions, almost half of which comes 
from passenger cars burning fossil fuels. These emissions warm the planet 
and make weather more extreme. In the U.S. alone,
storms caused by climate change caused $500 billion of damage 
in the last five years. So while gas is efficient, something so destructive
can't be the best fuel. The most common alternative
is electricity. Electric cars use a battery pack
and electric motor instead of the internal combustion engine
found in gas-powered cars, and must be charged at charging stations. With the right power infrastructure, they
can be as efficient as gas-powered cars. If powered by electricity generated
without fossil fuels, they can avoid greenhouse gas emissions 
entirely. They’re more expensive 
than gas-powered cars, but the cost difference has been
shrinking rapidly since 2010. The other alternatives to gasoline
are other liquid fuels. Many of these can be shipped and stored
using the same infrastructure as gasoline, and used in the same cars. They can also be carbon-neutral 
if they’re made using carbon dioxide from the atmosphere— meaning when we burn them, we release that
same carbon dioxide back into the air, and don't add to overall emissions. One approach to carbon-neutral fuel
is to capture carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combine its carbon
with the hydrogen in water. This creates hydrocarbons, 
the source of energy in fossil fuels— but without any emissions if the fuels 
are made using clean electricity. These fuels take up more space than an energetically equivalent
amount of gasoline— an obstacle to using them in cars. Another approach is to make carbon-neutral
fuels from plants, which sequester carbon from the air 
through photosynthesis. But growing the plants also has 
to be carbon neutral— which rules out many crops
that require fertilizer, a big contributor 
to greenhouse gas emissions. So the next generation of these fuels
must be made from either plant waste or plants that don't require
fertilizer to grow. Biofuels can be about as efficient
as gasoline, though not all are. For a fuel to be the best option, 
people have to be able to afford it. Unfortunately, the high upfront costs
of implementing new technologies and heavy subsidies for the producers 
of fossil fuels, mean that almost every green technology is more expensive than 
its fossil-fuel-based cousin. This cost difference is known
as a green premium. Governments have already started
subsidizing electric vehicles to help make up the difference. In some places, depending 
on the costs of electricity and gas, electric cars can already
be cheaper overall, despite the higher cost of the car. The other alternatives are trickier, 
for now— zero-carbon liquid fuels can be
double the price of gasoline or more. Innovators are doing everything
they can to bring green premiums down, because in the end, the best fuel 
will be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a drawback of using fuels from crude oil?
Options: A. Oil spills and costly environmental damage, B. Air pollution that causes health risks, C. Greenhouse gas emissions, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of energy in gasoline? Options: A. Hydrogen, B. Hydrocarbons, C. Oxygen, D. Carbon dioxide Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is one of the major drawbacks of using fuels derived from crude oil? Options: A. They are not energy dense, B. They cause environmental damage and air pollution, C. They are expensive to produce, D. They are not widely available Correct Option: B
Question 3: If an electric car is powered by electricity generated without fossil fuels, what can it avoid? Options: A. Greenhouse gas emissions, B. Air pollution, C. Environmental damage, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the main advantage of using carbon-neutral liquid fuels made from plants? Options: A. They are more energy dense than gasoline, B. They can be shipped and stored using the same infrastructure as gasoline, C. They can avoid greenhouse gas emissions entirely, D. They are cheaper to produce than gasoline Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the "green premium"? Options: A. The cost difference between a gas-powered car and an electric car, B. The cost difference between a fossil-fuel-based technology and its green alternative, C. The cost of implementing new technologies, D. The cost of subsidizing electric vehicles Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why are biofuels made from plants that require fertilizer not considered carbon neutral? Options: A. Because fertilizer is expensive to produce, B. Because fertilizer contributes to greenhouse gas emissions, C. Because plants that require fertilizer are not widely available, D. Because biofuels made from plants are not energy dense Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one approach to making carbon-neutral fuels? Options: A. Capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combining it with hydrogen from water, B. Making fuels from plants that require fertilizer, C. Using fossil fuels to generate electricity, D. Implementing new technologies to reduce emissions Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is a major obstacle to using carbon-neutral liquid fuels in cars? Options: A. They are not energy dense, B. They are expensive to produce, C. They take up more space than an energetically equivalent amount of gasoline, D. They are not widely available Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can governments help make green technologies more affordable for consumers? Options: A. By subsidizing fossil fuel producers, B. By implementing new technologies to reduce emissions, C. By subsidizing electric vehicles and other green technologies, D. By increasing the cost of fossil fuels Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal for the next generation of fuels? Options: A. To be more energy dense than gasoline, B. To be cheaper to produce than gasoline, C. To be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for the planet, D. To be widely available Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, as it asks about the drawbacks of using fuels derived from crude oil. The options also align with the ground truth MCQ, with option B mentioning environmental damage and air pollution, which are also mentioned in the correct option of the ground truth MCQ. While the generated MCQ does not explicitly mention greenhouse gas emissions or oil spills, it captures the overall intent of the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Question 9: How can governments help make green technologies more affordable for consumers? Options: A. By subsidizing fossil fuel producers, B. By implementing new technologies to reduce emissions, C. By subsidizing electric vehicles and other green technologies, D. By increasing the cost of fossil fuels Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal for the next generation of fuels? Options: A. To be more energy dense than gasoline, B. To be cheaper to produce than gasoline, C. To be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for the planet, D. To be widely available Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. 

This question addresses the carbon neutrality of plant-based fuels, specifically highlighting the issue with using plants that require fertilizer, which is a key point related to the ground truth MCQ's assertion that not all plant-based fuels are carbon-neutral.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Historically, most cars have run 
on gasoline, but that doesn’t have to be
the case in the future: other liquid fuels and electricity
can also power cars. So what are the differences 
between these options? And which one’s best? Gasoline is refined from crude oil, a fossil fuel extracted
from deep underground. The energy in gasoline comes from a class
of molecules called hydrocarbons. There are hundreds of different
hydrocarbons in crude oil, and different ones are used 
to make gasoline and diesel— which is why you can't use
them interchangeably. Fuels derived from crude oil
are extremely energy dense, bringing a lot of bang for your buck. Unfortunately, they have many drawbacks. Oil spills cause environmental damage
and cost billions of dollars to clean up. Air pollution from burning 
fossil fuels like these kills 4.5 million people each year. And transportation accounts for 16%
of global greenhouse gas emissions, almost half of which comes 
from passenger cars burning fossil fuels. These emissions warm the planet 
and make weather more extreme. In the U.S. alone,
storms caused by climate change caused $500 billion of damage 
in the last five years. So while gas is efficient, something so destructive
can't be the best fuel. The most common alternative
is electricity. Electric cars use a battery pack
and electric motor instead of the internal combustion engine
found in gas-powered cars, and must be charged at charging stations. With the right power infrastructure, they
can be as efficient as gas-powered cars. If powered by electricity generated
without fossil fuels, they can avoid greenhouse gas emissions 
entirely. They’re more expensive 
than gas-powered cars, but the cost difference has been
shrinking rapidly since 2010. The other alternatives to gasoline
are other liquid fuels. Many of these can be shipped and stored
using the same infrastructure as gasoline, and used in the same cars. They can also be carbon-neutral 
if they’re made using carbon dioxide from the atmosphere— meaning when we burn them, we release that
same carbon dioxide back into the air, and don't add to overall emissions. One approach to carbon-neutral fuel
is to capture carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combine its carbon
with the hydrogen in water. This creates hydrocarbons, 
the source of energy in fossil fuels— but without any emissions if the fuels 
are made using clean electricity. These fuels take up more space than an energetically equivalent
amount of gasoline— an obstacle to using them in cars. Another approach is to make carbon-neutral
fuels from plants, which sequester carbon from the air 
through photosynthesis. But growing the plants also has 
to be carbon neutral— which rules out many crops
that require fertilizer, a big contributor 
to greenhouse gas emissions. So the next generation of these fuels
must be made from either plant waste or plants that don't require
fertilizer to grow. Biofuels can be about as efficient
as gasoline, though not all are. For a fuel to be the best option, 
people have to be able to afford it. Unfortunately, the high upfront costs
of implementing new technologies and heavy subsidies for the producers 
of fossil fuels, mean that almost every green technology is more expensive than 
its fossil-fuel-based cousin. This cost difference is known
as a green premium. Governments have already started
subsidizing electric vehicles to help make up the difference. In some places, depending 
on the costs of electricity and gas, electric cars can already
be cheaper overall, despite the higher cost of the car. The other alternatives are trickier, 
for now— zero-carbon liquid fuels can be
double the price of gasoline or more. Innovators are doing everything
they can to bring green premiums down, because in the end, the best fuel 
will be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Green premium is ______.
Options: A. A subsidy provided by the government, B. The cost of plant-based fuels, C. The cost difference between a clean technology and its fossil-fuel-based counterpart, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of energy in gasoline? Options: A. Hydrogen, B. Hydrocarbons, C. Oxygen, D. Carbon dioxide Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is one of the major drawbacks of using fuels derived from crude oil? Options: A. They are not energy dense, B. They cause environmental damage and air pollution, C. They are expensive to produce, D. They are not widely available Correct Option: B
Question 3: If an electric car is powered by electricity generated without fossil fuels, what can it avoid? Options: A. Greenhouse gas emissions, B. Air pollution, C. Environmental damage, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the main advantage of using carbon-neutral liquid fuels made from plants? Options: A. They are more energy dense than gasoline, B. They can be shipped and stored using the same infrastructure as gasoline, C. They can avoid greenhouse gas emissions entirely, D. They are cheaper to produce than gasoline Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the "green premium"? Options: A. The cost difference between a gas-powered car and an electric car, B. The cost difference between a fossil-fuel-based technology and its green alternative, C. The cost of implementing new technologies, D. The cost of subsidizing electric vehicles Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why are biofuels made from plants that require fertilizer not considered carbon neutral? Options: A. Because fertilizer is expensive to produce, B. Because fertilizer contributes to greenhouse gas emissions, C. Because plants that require fertilizer are not widely available, D. Because biofuels made from plants are not energy dense Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one approach to making carbon-neutral fuels? Options: A. Capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combining it with hydrogen from water, B. Making fuels from plants that require fertilizer, C. Using fossil fuels to generate electricity, D. Implementing new technologies to reduce emissions Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is a major obstacle to using carbon-neutral liquid fuels in cars? Options: A. They are not energy dense, B. They are expensive to produce, C. They take up more space than an energetically equivalent amount of gasoline, D. They are not widely available Correct Option: C
Question 9: How can governments help make green technologies more affordable for consumers? Options: A. By subsidizing fossil fuel producers, B. By implementing new technologies to reduce emissions, C. By subsidizing electric vehicles and other green technologies, D. By increasing the cost of fossil fuels Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal for the next generation of fuels? Options: A. To be more energy dense than gasoline, B. To be cheaper to produce than gasoline, C. To be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for the planet, D. To be widely available Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to define the term "green premium." The options provided in Question 5 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (B) accurately defining the term as the cost difference between a fossil-fuel-based technology and its green alternative.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Historically, most cars have run 
on gasoline, but that doesn’t have to be
the case in the future: other liquid fuels and electricity
can also power cars. So what are the differences 
between these options? And which one’s best? Gasoline is refined from crude oil, a fossil fuel extracted
from deep underground. The energy in gasoline comes from a class
of molecules called hydrocarbons. There are hundreds of different
hydrocarbons in crude oil, and different ones are used 
to make gasoline and diesel— which is why you can't use
them interchangeably. Fuels derived from crude oil
are extremely energy dense, bringing a lot of bang for your buck. Unfortunately, they have many drawbacks. Oil spills cause environmental damage
and cost billions of dollars to clean up. Air pollution from burning 
fossil fuels like these kills 4.5 million people each year. And transportation accounts for 16%
of global greenhouse gas emissions, almost half of which comes 
from passenger cars burning fossil fuels. These emissions warm the planet 
and make weather more extreme. In the U.S. alone,
storms caused by climate change caused $500 billion of damage 
in the last five years. So while gas is efficient, something so destructive
can't be the best fuel. The most common alternative
is electricity. Electric cars use a battery pack
and electric motor instead of the internal combustion engine
found in gas-powered cars, and must be charged at charging stations. With the right power infrastructure, they
can be as efficient as gas-powered cars. If powered by electricity generated
without fossil fuels, they can avoid greenhouse gas emissions 
entirely. They’re more expensive 
than gas-powered cars, but the cost difference has been
shrinking rapidly since 2010. The other alternatives to gasoline
are other liquid fuels. Many of these can be shipped and stored
using the same infrastructure as gasoline, and used in the same cars. They can also be carbon-neutral 
if they’re made using carbon dioxide from the atmosphere— meaning when we burn them, we release that
same carbon dioxide back into the air, and don't add to overall emissions. One approach to carbon-neutral fuel
is to capture carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and combine its carbon
with the hydrogen in water. This creates hydrocarbons, 
the source of energy in fossil fuels— but without any emissions if the fuels 
are made using clean electricity. These fuels take up more space than an energetically equivalent
amount of gasoline— an obstacle to using them in cars. Another approach is to make carbon-neutral
fuels from plants, which sequester carbon from the air 
through photosynthesis. But growing the plants also has 
to be carbon neutral— which rules out many crops
that require fertilizer, a big contributor 
to greenhouse gas emissions. So the next generation of these fuels
must be made from either plant waste or plants that don't require
fertilizer to grow. Biofuels can be about as efficient
as gasoline, though not all are. For a fuel to be the best option, 
people have to be able to afford it. Unfortunately, the high upfront costs
of implementing new technologies and heavy subsidies for the producers 
of fossil fuels, mean that almost every green technology is more expensive than 
its fossil-fuel-based cousin. This cost difference is known
as a green premium. Governments have already started
subsidizing electric vehicles to help make up the difference. In some places, depending 
on the costs of electricity and gas, electric cars can already
be cheaper overall, despite the higher cost of the car. The other alternatives are trickier, 
for now— zero-carbon liquid fuels can be
double the price of gasoline or more. Innovators are doing everything
they can to bring green premiums down, because in the end, the best fuel 
will be both affordable for consumers and sustainable for our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The best fuel is _______.
Options: A. Electrofuel, B. Affordable and sustainable, C. Produced through photosynthesis, D. Water-based hydrocarbon
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
No matter how we make electricity,
it takes up space. Electricity from coal requires mines,
and plants to burn it and convert the heat into electricity. Nuclear power takes uranium mines,
facilities to refine the uranium, a reactor, and a place to store 
the spent fuel safely. Renewable energy needs wind turbines 
or solar panels. How much space depends
on the power source. Say you wanted to power a 10-watt 
light bulb with fossil fuels like coal. Fossil fuels can produce 
up to 2,000 watts per square meter, so it would only take a credit card-sized
chunk of land to power the light bulb. With nuclear power, you might only
need an area about the size of the palms of your hands. With solar power, you’d need at least
0.3 square meters of land— twice the size of a cafeteria tray. Wind power would take roughly
7 square meters— about half the size of a parking space— 
to power the bulb. When you consider the space needed 
to power cities, countries, and the whole world,
it adds up fast. Today, the world uses 3 trillion watts 
of electricity. To power the entire world 
with only fossil fuels, you’d need at least about 1,200
square kilometers of space— roughly the area of Grand Bahama island. With nuclear energy, you’d need almost
four times as much space at a minimum— roughly 4,000 square kilometers, 
a little less than the area of Delaware. With solar, you’d need at least
95,000 square kilometers, approximately the area of South Korea. With wind power, you’d need two million—
about the area of Mexico. For each power source, there’s variability
in how much power it can generate per square meter, but these numbers give us a general
sense of the space needed. Of course, building energy infrastructure
in a desert, a rainforest, a town, or even in the ocean 
are completely different prospects. And energy sources monopolize the space 
they occupy to very different extents. Take wind power. Wind turbines need to be spread out—
sometimes half a kilometer apart— so that the turbulence from one turbine doesn’t reduce the efficiency 
of the others. So, much of the land needed 
to generate wind power is still available for other uses. But the baseline amount of space
still matters, because cities and other densely populated
areas have high electricity demands, and space near them is often limited. Our current power infrastructure 
works best when electricity is generated
where and when it’s needed, rather than being stored or sent
across long distances. Still, space demands are only
part of the equation. As of 2020, 2/3 of our electricity
comes from fossil fuels. Every year, electricity generation 
is responsible for about 27% of the more than 50 billion tons 
of greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, accelerating climate change 
and all its harms. So although fossil fuels require the least
space of our existing technologies, we can’t continue to rely on them. Cost is another consideration. Nuclear plants don’t emit greenhouse gases
and don’t require much space, but they’re way more expensive to build
than solar panels or wind turbines, and have waste to deal with. Renewables have almost no marginal costs— unlike with plants powered 
by fossil fuels, you don’t need to keep purchasing fuel 
to generate electricity. But you do need lots of wind and sunlight, which are more available in some places 
than others. No single approach will be
the best option to power the entire world while eliminating
harmful greenhouse gas emissions. For some places, nuclear power
might be the best option for replacing fossil fuels. Others, like the U.S., 
have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To produce electricity from nuclear power, we need ________.
Options: A. Uranium mines, B. To burn plants, C. Solar panels, D. Wind turbine
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason why electricity generation requires a significant amount of space? Options: A. The need for fuel storage, B. The size of the power plants, C. The different components required for each power source (e.g., mines, refineries, reactors), D. The high demand for electricity Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following power sources would require the least amount of space to power a 10-watt light bulb? Options: A. Solar power, B. Wind power, C. Nuclear power, D. Fossil fuels Correct Option: D
Question 3: If the world were to be powered entirely by solar energy, approximately how much space would be required? Options: A. 1,200 square kilometers, B. 4,000 square kilometers, C. 95,000 square kilometers, D. 2 million square kilometers Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a significant advantage of wind power in terms of land use? Options: A. Wind turbines can be built close together, B. Wind turbines require a small amount of land, C. Much of the land needed for wind power is still available for other uses, D. Wind turbines can be built in densely populated areas Correct Option: C
Question 5: According to the transcript, what percentage of greenhouse gas emissions is attributed to electricity generation each year? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 27%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 6: A city is looking to transition from fossil fuels to a cleaner energy source. Considering the high electricity demands and limited space, which of the following options might be the most suitable? Options: A. Solar power, B. Wind power, C. Nuclear power, D. Hydroelectric power Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a significant disadvantage of nuclear power plants compared to solar panels or wind turbines? Options: A. High greenhouse gas emissions, B. High construction costs, C. Limited fuel availability, D. Land requirements Correct Option: B
Question 8: Which of the following statements is true about renewable energy sources? Options: A. They have high marginal costs, B. They require a lot of fuel to generate electricity, C. They are only suitable for small-scale electricity generation, D. They have almost no marginal costs Correct Option: D
Question 9: Why is it challenging to rely solely on one approach to power the entire world while eliminating greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. The high cost of renewable energy sources, B. The limited availability of fossil fuels, C. The varying suitability of different power sources for different regions, D. The lack of technological advancements in the energy sector Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, what should be done to improve power sources across the board? Options: A. Increase reliance on fossil fuels, B. Decrease funding for renewable energy research, C. Make power sources safer, easier to store, and transport, D. Implement a single, universal energy source Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6, but it is not an exact match. However, Question 6 does discuss nuclear power as a viable option.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that specifically asks about the components required for nuclear power. Unfortunately, no such question exists among the provided generated MCQs.

However, if I had to choose the closest match based on the content and the fact that nuclear power is mentioned, I would say Question 6 is the closest match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. across long distances. Still, space demands are only
part of the equation. As of 2020, 2/3 of our electricity
comes from fossil fuels. Every year, electricity generation 
is responsible for about 27% of the more than 50 billion tons 
of greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, accelerating climate change 
and all its harms. So although fossil fuels require the least
space of our existing technologies, we can’t continue to rely on them. Cost is another consideration. Nuclear plants don’t emit greenhouse gases
and don’t require much space, but they’re way more expensive to build
than solar panels or wind turbines, and have waste to deal with. Renewables have almost no marginal costs— unlike with plants powered 
by fossil fuels, you don’t need to keep purchasing fuel 
to generate electricity. But you do need lots of wind and sunlight, which are more available in some places 
than others. No single approach will be
the best option to power the entire world while eliminating
harmful greenhouse gas emissions. For some places, nuclear power
might be the best option for replacing fossil fuels. Others, like the U.S., 
have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false? The amount of space needed to light a 10-watt light bulb depends on the power sources being used.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
No matter how we make electricity,
it takes up space. Electricity from coal requires mines,
and plants to burn it and convert the heat into electricity. Nuclear power takes uranium mines,
facilities to refine the uranium, a reactor, and a place to store 
the spent fuel safely. Renewable energy needs wind turbines 
or solar panels. How much space depends
on the power source. Say you wanted to power a 10-watt 
light bulb with fossil fuels like coal. Fossil fuels can produce 
up to 2,000 watts per square meter, so it would only take a credit card-sized
chunk of land to power the light bulb. With nuclear power, you might only
need an area about the size of the palms of your hands. With solar power, you’d need at least
0.3 square meters of land— twice the size of a cafeteria tray. Wind power would take roughly
7 square meters— about half the size of a parking space— 
to power the bulb. When you consider the space needed 
to power cities, countries, and the whole world,
it adds up fast. Today, the world uses 3 trillion watts 
of electricity. To power the entire world 
with only fossil fuels, you’d need at least about 1,200
square kilometers of space— roughly the area of Grand Bahama island. With nuclear energy, you’d need almost
four times as much space at a minimum— roughly 4,000 square kilometers, 
a little less than the area of Delaware. With solar, you’d need at least
95,000 square kilometers, approximately the area of South Korea. With wind power, you’d need two million—
about the area of Mexico. For each power source, there’s variability
in how much power it can generate per square meter, but these numbers give us a general
sense of the space needed. Of course, building energy infrastructure
in a desert, a rainforest, a town, or even in the ocean 
are completely different prospects. And energy sources monopolize the space 
they occupy to very different extents. Take wind power. Wind turbines need to be spread out—
sometimes half a kilometer apart— so that the turbulence from one turbine doesn’t reduce the efficiency 
of the others. So, much of the land needed 
to generate wind power is still available for other uses. But the baseline amount of space
still matters, because cities and other densely populated
areas have high electricity demands, and space near them is often limited. Our current power infrastructure 
works best when electricity is generated
where and when it’s needed, rather than being stored or sent
across long distances. Still, space demands are only
part of the equation. As of 2020, 2/3 of our electricity
comes from fossil fuels. Every year, electricity generation 
is responsible for about 27% of the more than 50 billion tons 
of greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, accelerating climate change 
and all its harms. So although fossil fuels require the least
space of our existing technologies, we can’t continue to rely on them. Cost is another consideration. Nuclear plants don’t emit greenhouse gases
and don’t require much space, but they’re way more expensive to build
than solar panels or wind turbines, and have waste to deal with. Renewables have almost no marginal costs— unlike with plants powered 
by fossil fuels, you don’t need to keep purchasing fuel 
to generate electricity. But you do need lots of wind and sunlight, which are more available in some places 
than others. No single approach will be
the best option to power the entire world while eliminating
harmful greenhouse gas emissions. For some places, nuclear power
might be the best option for replacing fossil fuels. Others, like the U.S., 
have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How much electricity did the world use in the year 2020?
Options: A. 56 billion watts, B. 3 trillion watts, C. 1.5 trillion watts, D. 90 billion watts
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason why electricity generation requires a significant amount of space? Options: A. The need for fuel storage, B. The size of the power plants, C. The different components required for each power source (e.g., mines, refineries, reactors), D. The high demand for electricity Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following power sources would require the least amount of space to power a 10-watt light bulb? Options: A. Solar power, B. Wind power, C. Nuclear power, D. Fossil fuels Correct Option: D
Question 3: If the world were to be powered entirely by solar energy, approximately how much space would be required? Options: A. 1,200 square kilometers, B. 4,000 square kilometers, C. 95,000 square kilometers, D. 2 million square kilometers Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a significant advantage of wind power in terms of land use? Options: A. Wind turbines can be built close together, B. Wind turbines require a small amount of land, C. Much of the land needed for wind power is still available for other uses, D. Wind turbines can be built in densely populated areas Correct Option: C
Question 5: According to the transcript, what percentage of greenhouse gas emissions is attributed to electricity generation each year? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 27%, D. 50% Correct Option: C
Question 6: A city is looking to transition from fossil fuels to a cleaner energy source. Hydroelectric power Correct Option: C

They are only suitable for small-scale electricity generation, D. They have almost no marginal costs Correct Option: D

The limited availability of fossil fuels, C. The varying suitability of different power sources for different regions, D. The lack of technological advancements in the energy sector Correct Option: C

Decrease funding for renewable energy research, C. Make power sources safer, easier to store, and transport, D. Implement a single, universal energy source Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
No matter how we make electricity,
it takes up space. Electricity from coal requires mines,
and plants to burn it and convert the heat into electricity. Nuclear power takes uranium mines,
facilities to refine the uranium, a reactor, and a place to store 
the spent fuel safely. Renewable energy needs wind turbines 
or solar panels. How much space depends
on the power source. Say you wanted to power a 10-watt 
light bulb with fossil fuels like coal. Fossil fuels can produce 
up to 2,000 watts per square meter, so it would only take a credit card-sized
chunk of land to power the light bulb. With nuclear power, you might only
need an area about the size of the palms of your hands. With solar power, you’d need at least
0.3 square meters of land— twice the size of a cafeteria tray. Wind power would take roughly
7 square meters— about half the size of a parking space— 
to power the bulb. When you consider the space needed 
to power cities, countries, and the whole world,
it adds up fast. Today, the world uses 3 trillion watts 
of electricity. To power the entire world 
with only fossil fuels, you’d need at least about 1,200
square kilometers of space— roughly the area of Grand Bahama island. With nuclear energy, you’d need almost
four times as much space at a minimum— roughly 4,000 square kilometers, 
a little less than the area of Delaware. With solar, you’d need at least
95,000 square kilometers, approximately the area of South Korea. With wind power, you’d need two million—
about the area of Mexico. For each power source, there’s variability
in how much power it can generate per square meter, but these numbers give us a general
sense of the space needed. Of course, building energy infrastructure
in a desert, a rainforest, a town, or even in the ocean 
are completely different prospects. And energy sources monopolize the space 
they occupy to very different extents. Take wind power. Wind turbines need to be spread out—
sometimes half a kilometer apart— so that the turbulence from one turbine doesn’t reduce the efficiency 
of the others. So, much of the land needed 
to generate wind power is still available for other uses. But the baseline amount of space
still matters, because cities and other densely populated
areas have high electricity demands, and space near them is often limited. Our current power infrastructure 
works best when electricity is generated
where and when it’s needed, rather than being stored or sent
across long distances. Still, space demands are only
part of the equation. As of 2020, 2/3 of our electricity
comes from fossil fuels. Every year, electricity generation 
is responsible for about 27% of the more than 50 billion tons 
of greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, accelerating climate change 
and all its harms. So although fossil fuels require the least
space of our existing technologies, we can’t continue to rely on them. Cost is another consideration. Nuclear plants don’t emit greenhouse gases
and don’t require much space, but they’re way more expensive to build
than solar panels or wind turbines, and have waste to deal with. Renewables have almost no marginal costs— unlike with plants powered 
by fossil fuels, you don’t need to keep purchasing fuel 
to generate electricity. But you do need lots of wind and sunlight, which are more available in some places 
than others. No single approach will be
the best option to power the entire world while eliminating
harmful greenhouse gas emissions. For some places, nuclear power
might be the best option for replacing fossil fuels. Others, like the U.S., 
have the natural resources to get most or all of their electricity 
from renewables. And across the board, we should be working
to make our power sources better: safer in the case of nuclear, and easier to store and transport 
in the case of renewables.
